summary: This is an internal email from a prosecutor/investigator dated September 15, 2019, providing an update on the financial side of the Jeffrey Epstein investigation. It details the extensive review of Epstein's financial holdings, transactions, and relationships with various individuals and institutions, concluding that nothing actionable for criminal charges has been found. It references a Wall Street Journal reporter's inquiry about Epstein's charity Gratitude America and its Deutsche Bank account.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Central figure in the financial and sex-trafficking investigation. His financial holdings, transactions, and relationships with associates are the primary focus of the document.

persons.name: Joichi Ito
persons.role: Recipient of significant payments from Epstein
persons.context: Former director of the MIT Media Lab who received significant payments from Epstein, as noted by the investigator.

persons.name: Ehud Barak
persons.context: Former Prime Minister of Israel who is listed among individuals or entities that received payments from Epstein.

persons.name: Bruce Moskowitz
persons.context: Described as a close friend of President Trump and a Mar-A-Lago member, listed among individuals who received payments from Epstein.

persons.name: Noam Chomsky
persons.context: Prominent academic listed among individuals who received payments from Epstein.

persons.name: Woody Allen
persons.context: Filmmaker listed among individuals who received payments from Epstein.

persons.name: Glenn Dubin
persons.role: Billionaire with personal and financial connections to Epstein
persons.context: Listed among billionaires with whom Epstein had personal and financial connections.

persons.name: Barry Diller
persons.role: Billionaire with personal and financial connections to Epstein
persons.context: Listed among billionaires with whom Epstein had personal and financial connections.

persons.name: Leslie Wexner
persons.role: Billionaire with personal and financial connections to Epstein
persons.context: Listed among billionaires with whom Epstein had personal and financial connections. Noted as a source of a 'huge chunk of money' for Epstein in the 90s/early 00s.

persons.name: Henry Jarecki
persons.role: Billionaire with personal and financial connections to Epstein
persons.context: Listed among billionaires with whom Epstein had personal and financial connections.

persons.name: Andrew Farkas
persons.role: Billionaire with personal and financial connections to Epstein
persons.context: Listed among billionaires with whom Epstein had personal and financial connections.

persons.name: Leon Black
persons.role: Billionaire with personal and financial connections to Epstein
persons.context: Listed among billionaires with whom Epstein had personal and financial connections. His foundation controlled a $10 million grant to Epstein's Gratitude America charity.

persons.name: Anjan
persons.context: Attorney representing JPMorgan, with whom investigators spoke on Monday regarding financial records.

persons.name: Reed Brodsky
persons.context: Attorney representing Honeycomb Asset Management, a hedge fund in which Epstein invested nearly $100 million.

persons.name: Rebecca Davis O'Brien
persons.role: Reporter for The Wall Street Journal
persons.context: Journalist who emailed questions to the SDNY about Epstein's charity Gratitude America and its Deutsche Bank account, prompting the internal discussion.

persons.name: Nick
persons.context: Primary recipient of the internal investigative update email. Likely a prosecutor or lead investigator.

connections.description: Epstein received a 'huge chunk of money' from Wexner in the 1990s and early 2000s, which he then lived off of from investments.
Epstein had personal and financial connections to Black. Black's foundation controlled a $10 million grant to Epstein's Gratitude America charity in 2015.
Epstein had personal and financial connections to billionaire Glenn Dubin.
Epstein made significant payments to Joichi Ito of MIT.
Epstein made payments to entities relating to or for the benefit of former Israeli Prime Minister Ehud Barak.
Epstein made payments to entities relating to or for the benefit of Bruce Moskowitz, a close friend of President Trump.

events.title: $10M Grant to Gratitude America
events.description: Epstein's Virgin Islands-based charity, Gratitude America, received a $10 million grant from a foundation controlled by Leon Black.

events.title: Payments to Associate
events.description: An unnamed associate received approximately $20K in 2013 and 2014 in connection with her business, in addition to a previously known $250K payment.

events.title: Series of Payments to Associate
events.description: An unnamed associate received about a dozen payments between 2013 and 2019 in amounts ranging from $20-100K.

events.title: Bank Switch
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein switched his primary banking from JPMorgan to Deutsche Bank.

events.title: Alleged Ponzi Scheme Involvement
events.description: Hoffenberg allegations that Epstein was involved in a massive Ponzi scheme in the 1990s.

keyFacts: Investigators conducted an extensive financial review of Jeffrey Epstein but found nothing actionable for criminal charges, despite awareness of many transactions and relationships.

Epstein made payments to a wide array of prominent individuals and institutions, including Joichi Ito (MIT), Ehud Barak, Bruce Moskowitz, Noam Chomsky, Woody Allen, Harvard, MIT, and over 25 Eastern European models.
Epstein had personal and financial connections to billionaires including Glenn Dubin, Barry Diller, Leslie Wexner, Henry Jarecki, Andrew Farkas, and Leon Black.
Epstein's charity, Gratitude America, received a $10 million grant in 2015 from a foundation controlled by Leon Black and had a Deutsche Bank account.
Payments to alleged co-conspirators were primarily made from a specific trust account at Deutsche Bank, prompting investigators to seek earlier records from JPMorgan.
